Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations and Applications" that will be held at the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor on July 9-12, 2019.

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the topics of hyperbolic conservation laws, mathematical general relativity, compressible and incompressible fluids, boundary dispersive phenomena, fluid dynamics and kinetic theory. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at: https://mcaim.math.lsa.umich.edu/events/pde-conference/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "Conference on Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations and Applications" was held from the morning of July 9, till the noon of July 12, 2019, on the 10th floor of the Weiser Hall at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. It was attended by more than 120 participants, with 19 invited leading researchers speaking on topics ranging from hyperbolic conservation laws, mathematical general relativity, compressible and incompressible fluid, kinetic equations to dispersive equations, and involving  methods that are both deterministic and probabilistic.  A panel discussions was held to discuss new ideas, challenges and open problems in the subjects. And a poster session was held which fostered informal discussions on some further topics. Around 20 graduate students and postdoc researchers presented their works in the poster session. 

 

The conference provided a venue for researchers, junior and senior,  in inter-related research areas to discuss the most recent advances in respective subjects, and to interact and collaborate. New frontiers were identified and possible methods were discussed. 

 

NSF funding was solely used to defray the travel and lodging costs of the participating graduate students, postdocs and earlier career researchers who do not have other fundings, as well as the travel and partial lodging costs of the  invited speakers.
